pages.text: Columns are ubiquitous in Greco-Roman architecture. Caupona provides three composite orders of columns, in four materials: quartz, calcite, stone, and felsic_tuff.
Columns are composed of three parts: capital, shaft and plinth. These can be made of respective materials in the stonecutter. Specially, quartz columns require smooth quartz blocks.
An Ionian column has a classic spiral capital and a fluted shaft.
A Tuscan column has no complicated carvings on the capital, and the column shaft is not fluted. So its visual effect is relatively simple.
This order of column does not exist in reality, with its prototype being the Corinthian order. An acanthine column has a fluted shaft, and relief pattern that resemble leaves on its capital.
